content: scrappy block socks text and photos © liz harris 2019 when you re a sock knitter for any amount of time whatsoever you end up accumulating the leftover scraps from just about every pair you make thus having a scrappy pattern or two in your pattern arsenal is just the ticket for these socks you will need 3 kinds of scraps a good portion of a solid for the cuff heels and toes a multicolor for rounds in between your blocks and multiple highly contrasting colors for the blocks themselves careful color selection ties all of these scraps together start with a multicolor yarn this will be used at the beginning of the fair isle pattern and serve as dividing stripes for your blocks this can be a leftover from a self-striping yarn or a wildly variegated yarn from an indie dyer let that be your starting point and then choose a solid color yarn or yarns that you have in sufficient quantity for the cuffs heels and toes this will really tie everything together i have used all one color but you can mix it up then move on to the scraps for the blocks themselves make sure that they contrast strongly with each and are in the same color family of the original multicolor yarn that you started with lay them all out on a table and see if they play nice together if one color stands out like a sore thumb toss it aside and save it for another project i recommend using solid colored or only lightly tonal or speckled yarns for the heel toes cuffs and blocks or the pattern will not be very evident i have chosen to make identical socks for my pair but you certainly don t have to mix it up go wild use up all those dang scraps oh and by the way since you re using up lots of odds and ends of yarn you will also be generating lots and lots of ends to weave in do yourself a favor and work them in as you go with a modified russian join like i do it slows you down a bit while you re actually doing it but after that your ends are anchored secure and dealt with and you don t have a 100 ends to weave in it s a solid join doesn t leave a knot and does not come undone please see the tutorial at my blog for an explicit step-by-step description complete with bunches of photos at https //lizzieknitzz com/2019/06/25/lets-all-join/ this pattern is appropriate for an intermediate level knitter familiar with fair isle knitting the gusset has some fairly explicit instructions that a beginner would likely struggle with expert knitters will find the pattern interesting as well and it should be a quick and fun knit for them i knit with 5 dpns stitches evenly distributed on 4 needles
